author: wired blogs
text: date: tue, 28 dec 1999 11:14:35 -0800 from: matthew davidian (matthewd@lightspeed.net)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: dvd hackers hit with lawsuitthis article fails to mention the reason behind the dvd "hack" in the first place ("dvd hackers hit with lawsuit," 28.dec.99). this was done so that linux users would be able to watch dvd movies on their computers; there is no dvd playback software available for linux prior to this.the "hack" does nothing to facilitate illegal copying of dvd right now because there is no viable distribution mechanism. there's no writable, portable mass storage device to copy the 4.7 - 9.4 gb files, and most people don't have enough bandwidth to transfer the files once they're decoded. that's not to say sometime in the future such capabilities won't be available, but these facts should shed some light on the "hackers'" motivations behind the dvd decoding software.the dvd industry neglected a market for its product and the market filled the need in its own "open source" tradition. there have also been some objections on slashdot about them claiming the reverse engineering was illegal. while i'm not a lawyer, there's a good chance the reverse engineering was legal. in addition, there is some doubt about the validity of delivering notices via email, as was done in this case, to the named defendants, as well as the success the dvd cca will have in prosecuting the defendants that are not located in the united states.
